BOOM BOOM... And then everyone is dead. The BOSS, who had been killing everyone at his will, suddenly has a change of heart. He let's himself to be killed to save the love of the kud.

The kid goes to the prison. And the girl, who has just met him 3-4 times, sends a letter that she will wait for him (the kid has got 25 years in prison or something).

title: Refreshing heist movie
review: Really refreshing gangster/heist movie. The music gives it just this little extra touch. Nice cinematography, you get the feeling that the scenes are build around the music.

title: One of Edgar Wright's Best!
review: Edgar Wright is one of my most favorite directors. And this film, illustrates his craft. Every character is well written, every scene is detailed to the last frame. And, of course, the soundtrack is excellent! The music coincides perfectly with the busy surroundings of Atlanta. The film is one of my most favorites by Edgar. And I hope he makes more films just as great as this.

title: Decent heistelling movie, to bad the female roles where weak
review: I really liked the build up in the intensity of the heist. Bought baby as a person and the gangsters where fine. But to believe Debora would follow him to the end after 3 meetings and 1 date I just cant buy. She didnt get enough depth and therefore she felt like the classic 'reward for the man' instead of an actual person in an actual relationship with baby. Thus the whole end felt very unsatisfying

title: GTA for winners
review:
Loved this.
Sound track was awesome followed with some great storytelling.
What you heard is what you'll dig, Jamie fox is top class.
If you don't like this it's your loss. Loved it and hope there's a follow up.

title: Brilliant action film
review:
'Baby Driver' is an excellent action movie directed by Edgar Wright, who's directing credits also include 'Shaun Of The Dead and 'Hot Fuzz'.
Ansel Elgort plays 'Baby', a young man who is a car-jacker turned getaway driver, following a car accident when he was young, suffers from tinnitus and listens to music through headphones to drown out the sound of the humming. He is pressured into working for crime kingpin 'Doc', played by Kevin Spacey, as the driver for a crew in a number of robberies. However, when he meets and falls in love with a beautiful young waitress, his life takes a drastic turn.
This is an extremely fast-paced, exciting movie with some of the best car chase action sequences I have seen on film. The direction is superb and the first act of this film just grabs you and takes you along for the ride with stunning cinematography. The writing, acting and direction of this film really make the story come alive and it feels genuinely believable. 'Baby' is a good person who is a great driver and he is drawn into something he'd rather not be in and is desperate to get out of. The criminals are seriously nasty as a major contrast to Baby's character.
The movie could be classed as an action-drama as there is real depth to the characters, it's personal but also very dark. There, of course, some really gripping action scenes, with incredible stunts.
The soundtrack of this movie utilises songs and music to perfection, and they all serve a purpose. They are so incorporated and integrated by the editing that they flow in perfect sync with the action your seeing.
The dialogue in the movie is witty at times, but you also get invested in the characters and their situation.
The casting is magnificent. Ansel Elgort is remarkable. He has a minimal amount of lines and so much of his performance relies on facial expressions, and you can read so much in his eyes. There are stellar performances from Jamie Foxx and John Hamm too. Kevin Spacey is on form yet again, delivering so much emotion without too much expression. This is something Spacey does so well, he can deliver a lot of dialogue very fast and in a deadpan manner so well, take a look at the film '21' as a great example.
Lily James plays 'Debora', the love interest for Baby, who appears halfway through the film.
But this is, for me, the weakest part of the film. From the intensity and speed of the first act, the second act is considerably slower. There is still some action happening but it's slowed down by the fact that it's difficult to invest in the romance. It was set up so quickly and there was no real character development or depth to it, and she makes life-changing decisions for both Baby and herself in a split second without much thought, and the relationship didn't feel strong enough to warrant or justify them, and the believability of the romance didn't really work for me
The third act picks it all back up again when Baby making choices about how he wants his future to be, and we get some more amazing action sequences and terrific performances.
It's down to the brilliance of the direction and the captivating performances given by the amazing actors that kept the film interesting, even when the romance fell flat.
As I said, the direction in this film is outstanding, there is barely a boring shot, everything looks so slick, the cinematography and camera work is excellent.
Aside from the romance which felt hurried, 'Baby Driver' is an entertaining and exciting movie with a great cast, great action and a fantastic soundtrack.

title: A standard heist film with fun music, engaging characters, and flashy driving.
review:
There are so many "heist" films nowadays that it's practically its own genre, with all the tropes and clichÃ©s that go with it. Consequently, when I learned that Edgar Wright had directed a heist film, my interest was piqued. Best known for his parody comedies, Shaun of the Dead(2004), Hot Fuzz (2007), and The World's End (2013), the film of his I have enjoyed the most is Scott Pilgrim vs. the World (2010). His style is distinct throughout these films, which is what I was hoping for in Baby Driver (2017).

While Wright's visual style is present in Baby Driver, it is muted, almost in the background of the standard heist framework. With an almost 1980's undertone, Baby Driver takes many cues from its predecessor, Drive (2011). Both feature an almost silent heist driver as the main character and plenty of entertaining driving sequences that are practically ballet on the boulevards. Fortunately, both films also focus on the characters, and not so much on the heist, giving personality to their actions. Aside from the likable and titular Baby (Ansel Elgort), Kevin Spacey seems to be satiated through all the scenery he chews (to entertaining effect), and Jon Hamm was almost recognizable with his rough stubble and attitude.

Granted, Baby Driver is not the goofball comedy I expected. Instead, the film is almost musical, revealing the rhythm in everything by overlaying the action on screen with a curated set-list of obscure and catchy tunes. Sure, the film feels more "mainstream," but it's also trying to do something new. Synching up bullets to rhythms and wads of cash to downbeats almost goes unnoticed unless you're taking in the whole experience. At the very least, we know what music Edgar Wright likes, and I must say that I approve (especially of the "Hocus Pocus" sequence, which is a song that should be in more action sequences (like Robocop (2014) did to similar effect)).

A standard heist film with fun music, engaging characters, and flashy driving, I give Baby Driver 4.0 stars out of 5.

title: Enjoy the ride, but silly
review: Enjoy it for what it is: cool chase scenes with a fun soundtrack. It's a popcorn flick. Shallow characters, shallow plot, and shallow heist. But it reminds me of action movies from the 90s.

title: Drifts Into Surprising Directions While Staying In Control
review:
As an original piece in a market full of sequels, reboots, and adaptations, the gritty, action-packed crime story that is "Baby Driver" rose up as one of the most iconic movies of this past year. This gave director Edgar Wright a lot to uphold worldwide, being given a chance to show Hollywood that new ideas are worth taking chances on. Through my eyes and ears, the feature proved its point to viewers everywhere and shined through as a wonderful example of original filmmaking, free of any and all previous lore or convention. So sit down, put on your favorite 80's beats, and let's talk about what made "Baby Driver" such a great thriller.
A young man known only as "Baby" (Ansel Elgort) has a debt to pay to a crime lord under the codename "Doc" (Kevin Spacey), and the only way he can do it is by being his number-one getaway driver for every heist he plans. Near the end of his repayment, Baby meets a waitress (Lily James) at Bo's Diner singing a wonderful song, and immediately falls for her; Debora, without the H. Baby and Debora share the same dream of driving down the highway for miles, nowhere to go, nothing to do, no one but each other-but Doc doesn't care to let his top driver quit that easily. Keeping himself busy with his perpetual music drowning out his childhood tinnitus (among many other things), Baby has to find a way to escape the villainous life he's being forcefully dragged into, though he has no idea the sacrifices he's gonna have to make to get his freedom and come clean for the future. I must say, while Elgort portrayed Baby splendidly, there unfortunately isn't anything spectacular I can mention about his performance in particular. However, Debora's character arc twists and pops out just as much as it should with James at its helm, and Jon Hamm & Jamie Foxx as two of the crucial criminals in the piece bring forth the brilliant grit needed to drive it home (no pun intended). Overall, it may feel that Elgort's part is carried by his castmates, but that's just another part of acting; making your scene partners look as good as possible.
I'll be honest, I'm not usually one for action movies (keep that in mind as I'm giving my final thoughts at the end). Even with that being said, "Baby Driver" managed to keep me on my toes and interested from start to finish. I immediately admired all of its cinematography, the crew with their cameras as skilled as Baby with a car. Eerie stills or slow-moving shots during enthralling exposition complement the occasional rapid cuts of harsh action that disorients you just as it's designed to before you're brought back on track. On top of a beautiful visual job, sound design was essential for this movie to succeed at all, being so focused on Baby's music that he always listens to. The way it becomes a character in and of itself is breathtaking. The old classic tunes lots of the audience will remember play when life's going great for him, then cut out completely to hear the cold, harsh city environment when it's not as such (might I add that several other movies have tried and failed to replicate the whole "classic soundtrack" thing, and this one nailed it). Moderately bright colors dominate the entire feature, even in its dreariest moments, providing a strange false sense of comfort that gives a completely different tone to certain scenes. "Baby Driver" makes the viewer broaden their views on adolescent criminals, refine ideas of healthy and unhealthy relationships, and discover how to pull through toward one dream at the cost of another; at least, that's what I got from it, and I hope you do, as well.
I'm going to say what I always do as to the demographic of this movie; if you think you'll like it, you probably will. So long as you know what you're getting into with the R-rating (i.e. blood and guts galore), it's the perfect balance of great stunts and a greater story. For a fresh product to lay our eyes on, I say it's just what the doctor ordered. Overall, it gets an 8/10 from me.

title: This film perfectly combines a great soundtrack and story
review: A stylistic thrill ride. Baby Driver does well what a lot of movies don't do well in this genre. Edgar Wright's brilliant artistic style blends nicely with this musical thrill ride. This film raises the bar for action movies and the Fast and Furious franchise could take some notes on how a car chase scene is done right. Overall this film perfectly combines a great soundtrack and Edgar Wright's artistic style.

title: 50 dead bodies, 100 car crashes, 1000 shots fired with predictable ending
review: The only reason that I gave this film a 5 and not less is because it was saved by the superb (10) acting of Ansel Elgort and great (8) acting by Lily James and the chemistry (9) between them that was totally "young love" believable. Jamie Foxx as a bad guy thug, Yawn, been there, done that. Spacey as the brains and boss of the operations added nothing unique to his all too familiar "Man Who Knows All Essentially Monotone" style of portraying characters over the years, another Big Yawn. I predicted that the film would have one of two endings, Everybody Dies or a Happily Ever After outcome; and Guess What? It did.

title: Yeah BABY!
review:
Meet "Baby" (Ansel Elgort), a young, male, getaway driver who also happens to have Tinnitus. Baby works for a crime boss who calls himself "Doc" (played perfectly by Kevin Spacey). Doc is known for crafting robberies using different teams each time. No matter who is in the team (normally thugs or violent criminals), Baby is called upon as the perfect getaway driver for the job. After completing what was announced to be his "last getaway job", Baby wishes to live a normal life, even more so after he meets a young girl named Debora and falls in love. Baby soon discovers that he can't escape his old life just yet...

This film is directed by Edgar Wright, whose resume of films include smashing hits such as Shaun of the Dead, Hot Fuzz & Scott Pilgrim VS the World. Once again, Edgar Wright delivers another film with clever action sequences and an audio track that will have you leaving the cinema wanting to purchase the film's soundtrack (on vinyl naturally). I was amazed during musical numbers just how many sound effects were in time with the music and I cannot deny how much fun it was to see. The list of effects includes Gunshots, footsteps, car engines, phones ringing and the list goes on. All of these sounds are critical to the film's soundtrack and also assist in how the film is overall paced.

The criminal cast in Baby Driver is a cast loaded with fun and talent. Actors Jon Hamm, Elza Gonzalez and Jamie Foxx all added a wide range of chemistry, all carrying something different. Ultimately, their actions as characters become unpredictable and it was surprising to see where they end up. The stand out from the extra cast members was easily Jamie Foxx for me- I enjoyed seeing his delivery of witty one liners. Overall, you can tell the actors here are all enjoying the film themselves.

With an opening that gets the cinema crowd fueled for the ride, Baby Driver does feel like it slows down in its gears until the 3rd act where it once again becomes a fast paced film. In the slower middle section, we watch Baby discover a new love, even a new job, until Baby is forced into action once again. The romance in this film is also a little cheesy as characters fall in love with each after one date, to the point they are both prepared to leave the city forever in just in a snap of short time. This isn't a massive issue for me, but for some it may come across as a very corny romance sequence.

Overall, Baby Driver, as expected, delivers the goods. With an overall fast paced ride at the start and finish of the film, sadly the slower portions in the middle hold back the film. Director Edgar Wright has captured and created a film with solid sound effects, car stunts, a great soundtrack and by working with a talented cast line, the film will leave most of the cinema audiences shocked and stunned. As expected for an Edgar Wright film, there's some fun to be had here.

8.3/10 Walkden Entertainment

title: Good
review: Good movie, good storyline, fun to watch but less action behind the wheels

title: From cool car moves to cool feet moves...
review:
A new level of creep with recent events.

That's a lot of colors iPods.

The same location? Stupid.

The waitress is gonna happen by right?

He's sweet and a little clever.

They better not find his recorder of someone will be out of tune.

This is bananas they trust the kid now.

Not smart to punch the driver.

Damn!

He ran the tables. Cool.

Take the glasses off!

It's a trap!

title: Love this movie. Hate Mr. Precious
review: Great movie. Had to deduct points for casting Jamie. Foxx always comes across as such a precious darling. I'm sure he loves on himself when just looking upon his own reflection. Other than that/him...great movie

title: Fascinating and different
review: This could have been your classic action flick and yes, it's a bit silly and over the top at times, but Baby was sweet and an unusual, but interesting character to get to know and follow around. But what really makes this film stand out is the soundtrack. It's incredible how they incorporated each song into the movie, sometimes with little details here and there, sometimes very obvious, but always on beat. It made the whole film just run so smoothly and 2 hours passed like they were just a couple minutes. I also love the fact that the score is treated more like a character than just background noise added in post - it's interactive and always present in a way I've never seen it before. My eyes were glued to the screen from start to finish, because I wanted to find all the little things that were all perfectly synched. Very glad I watched this

title: Edgar Wright is one of the most creative directors of our time
review: With Baby Driver, Edgar Wright has, once again, proved himself as one of the most creative directors of our time. This movie is refreshingly original. It's an action/musical hybrid, complete with carefully choreographed car chases and gunfights timed to a toe-tapping soundtrack. It's darker than I thought it was going to be, but I still couldn't stop smiling the whole time during this film.

title: Watch it like if you are reading a comic book
review: I liked this film a lot. Cast/car scenes/editing/cinematography/.../ are great. The plot is not mind blowing, but if you look at it without judgment it keeps your attention and emotion till the end. It's a great idea executed brilliantly. It's not going to help understand the laws of our universe or open your eyes about life and love. Just good entertainment. Sometimes it's what I like. When it's good and original.

title: Sounds familiar?
review:
• mostly silent male protagonist
  • who is extraoreinarily good at driving
  • does getaway driver jobs for heists
  • falls in love
  • one job he was hesitant to take goes incredibly wrong, people get shot
  • former peaceful and nonviolent driver goes bananas to keep himself and the girl he loves
safe

Though it is vastly different in tone compared to Drive by Refn, these almost identical crucial plot points kinda make it seem like a more comedy heavy remake. It's still fun to watch, just a little less impressive.

I also didn't love that ending. In Drive he wins the battle but loses the girl, despite saving her. Here, the girl is willing to risk it all, sacrifice her life for a guy who she (as it appears) met twice and then went on to kill somebody and goes to jail for 5 years. And apparently everything is fine after his prison release (except if the last scene only plays in his imagination). Man, that really must be love!

title: a fairy tale for nostalgic people, which means everyone these days
review:
A beautiful movie paced just right, with thrilling chase scenes, a killer soundtrack, witty dialogue, and characters that stand out--but is it too much to ask for a probable plot? A fitting homage to old songs and action flicks, I won't say that the film is ruined by cliches, and it is definitely entertaining. But there just wasn't enough emotional context to the film, and the turning points in characters' decisions are just taken for granted--everything feels so cartoonish.
I am almost sorry I just criticized this film; I absolutely loved watching it, but felt kind of cheated because I got carried away by its music(and Lily James). If you're in a nostalgic mood, watch the film by all means. Just don't think too much. And do remember that there are actual old movies, if you are in the mood for remembering the good old days.

title: Like it
review: Realy enjoyable movie that you can watch over and over.

title: Brilliant mix of music and film
review:
Plot: so-so... Acting: so-so...

Combination of excellent tracks from the 60s until present day: Like nothing I have ever seen before. Playful and entertaining.

title: Bold Baby Driver
review: The movie grasps your focus early on but misses on the momentum somewhere in between. Would have loved a more exploratory ending but it does remain honest to what it wanted as a movie. Overall, the movie was a good one with satisfactory screenplay and cinematography.

title: When an action movie is also fun!
review:
I don't remember seeing Baby Driver being advertised much or if it did it hasn't stay in my head as such. So i don't know if there was a lot of hype cause i see a lot of Ratings and Reviews here so it must have been very popular. Anyway i had it on my watchlist and when i watched it, it came as a nice surprise to me!

Where to start? The cas is very rich to the point Bernthal is not even secondary role-and he could because he has very little screentime-. Baby's relationship with his step dad is adorable. I liked his hearing gimmick and the music added a lot of points to the movie, especially the late chase song choice was on point. The weird stuff with the mixtapes were also good.

The romance was nice, kind of cliche but in a good way. Fox's crazy character acted as a secondary villain next to Spacey and Elgort carried his weight nicely as a protagonist. The heist sequences were well executed, as were the chases and the drive scenes.

In a suprising twist, Spacey's character held up his end of the deal in the end and then some more, as he sacrificed himself for a good cause, something you don't see very often from these type of people! And Karma can be a b*itch but it can also be rewarding and it was very satisfying that in the end the good deeds that Baby did and kept his good character made a difference in court.

It was a fun and entertaining movie in various ways, the action was there, you have a few laughs along the way and overall i think it's very enjoyable for its specific kind. 9/10

title: Very entertaining movie
review: Simple. Some of these reviews are asinine. It's not perfect. But the driving scenes are top notch. Great selection of music and everyone played their role well

title: Coolest!
review: Don't expect anything, just see it with an empty mind. ACTING was fabulous from all the LEAD ACTORS which contains 2 oscar ACTORS. Soundtrack was absolutely brilliant. Chasing sequences were amazing.Bad can't be forgiven, used that perfectly.

title: AWESOME ACTION ADVENTURE!!!
review: I absolutely love this movie, as with all movies, there are plot holes and different things that should have been done different. Overall I thought Baby was adorable! I couldn't stand Jamie Foxx's character it was absolutely disgusting! Glad when they got rid of his a$$ LOL. Kevin Spacey was also awesome in this movie. It would have been nicer to have a bigger backstory on Baby and him and Docs relationship. Overall the music was awesome and the Fast and Furious driving scenes were amazing. I hear they are working on a sequel, that would be awesome as well.

title: A fun foray into a music video
review: While the plot of this movie falls apart and wanders quite dangerously in the middle of the film, the characters are compelling and the music sweeps the audience along on the many, many car chases. Young Baby (named thus for the sake of dramatic intrigue) is a car thief and getaway driver prodigy, working for a crime boss. A childhood injury has left him mostly deaf, and his reliance on loud rhythmic music propels his life and his driving in a fantastically devil-may-care fashion. The musical soundtrack of this film features many pop culture songs, as well as several pre-21st-century tunes, and provides a sense of momentum to otherwise stagnating dialogue or over-long chase scenes. Ansel Elgorts well-timed movements, and the rapid cuts and suddenly changing camera angles are well done, if repetitive. Overall, the film feels more like an hour-long music video than a movie with music attached but is nevertheless rather enjoyable.

title: Like one long ipod commercial
review:
While it certainly had its moments, at its core this is a getaway movie heavily focused on its soundtrack. The music itself seems to come from a specific period of maybe 1960s r&b, and its all decent enough but personally i think it makes a poor substitute for dialogue, since i signed up for a movie and not a music video.

Some of the characters were okay, but mostly everyone was puzzled as to why our protagonist spoke very little. I was too. Ironically they couldve cut out some dialogue that just seemed repetitive in like of his character. Its like the dialogue thats used in other dramas to tell the viewer what to expect from a character, and then that same pattern keeps continuing throughout the entirety of the film.

Overall, decent but nothing too exceptional. The driving sequence in the first 10m was the best part of the film and the rest failed to live up to that one by any measure.

title: Simply Edgar Wright at his average level.
review: This film is great, I love the witty humor at times, I adore the characters and their interactions, the dialogue is very good and really well written. This film is exactly what you should expect from Wright. Every single actor and actress are great, even Kevin spacey acts quite well here (don't like Kevin, just his acting). Jon Hamm's role was exceptional and he was great in the role of criminal with a good heart. Ansel Elgort was the perfect choice for Baby and of course the soundtrack was perfectly fitting for this movies tone. Overall 10 BATS out of 10.

title: Love it
review: Good music, good shots, good chasing scenes and action. All in all a pretty good movie.

title: Baby Driver Is Accelerating To New Heights
review:
Baby Driver, directed by Edgar Wright, starring Ansel Elgort, Lily James, Kevin Spacey, Jon Hamm, Jon Bernthal, and Jamie Foxx: tells the story about the life of our main character, Baby. Baby likes to make music with people's conversations that he hears, he's partially deaf, and he's an exceptional escape driver for criminals because he's trying to pay off a debt that he owes to a crime boss named Doc, played by Kevin Spacey. Baby was also traumatized as a child due to being in a car crash that killed both his parents. He copes with this by listening to music to tune out his past and becoming extremely skillful at driving. For a while, Baby makes a good amount of money and almost pays off his debt, but then he meets a girl named Deborah who is played by Lily James, in which all goes downhill from there. Baby Driver displays masterful cinematography in its action scenes and an excellent soundtrack that compliments the mood of each one. This combination will leave any moviegoer wanting more.
To start off, Baby Driver's opening scene already sets up the level of camerawork quality to be expected of the entire film. As Baby's crew of criminals begins their raid on the bank, Baby is busy jamming out to a song he's listening to. The camera pans around him, displaying him singing and tapping the steering wheel as the song plays. When the car escape scene actually starts, the superb camera work is presented to the audience. What makes the cinematography so great is the variety and quality of the angles the car chase is filmed from. Different scenes that show different perceptions of the chase without being over the top really make this action segment seem real and makes you genuinely feel the tension of the scene. Later in the movie, there's a running chase scene that includes Baby escaping from a heist. The camera work is really good here because even though the action is chaotic with a lot of events occurring, the camera doesn't shake excessively. A common action movie flaw is the amount of camera shaking that occurs. While camera shaking does make some scenes feel more intense, too much camera shaking can make someone dizzy or blur the scene, making it difficult to watch. The transitions in this particular action scene are impressive and creative as well, as there's a section where policemen are chasing Baby down a hallway and the camera has a view from the side. Every time the camera is blocked by a pillar in the hall, it switches to a side view of the policemen and then it cuts back to Baby. The cinematography of the movie overall makes the viewer appreciate how well executed the action scenes are in the movie. 
While action scenes being executed well is a major factor in whether a movie is good or not, the soundtrack is equally as important. A soundtrack can make a mediocre action scene into a great one due to adding background sound that keeps the movie watcher interested. An action scene such as car chase would have noise like cars crashing, horns being honked, and the sound of bullets hitting the car. While that's not a bad thing, these noises can become repetitive, and even boring. In order to fix that, adding a soundtrack that compliments the scene enhances it by a considerable amount. However, a soundtrack that is overbearing can totally ruin an action scene as well. Music should be complimenting an action scene and the tone it creates; it shouldn't be forcing a tone onto the watcher. In Baby Driver, the music doesn't overwhelm the audience, but instead fits perfectly with the action. The music in Baby Driver isn't creating the tone; it's enhancing the tone that already has been established. One of the other additional soundtrack features that the movie includes is the syncing of the action scenes with the music. Gunshots and bullets hitting their target are all synced to the beat of the instrumental. This adds to the enhancing of the scene, as the soundtrack is directly interacting with the action. Also, this form of syncing is generally hard to pull off because if it's done wrong, it can completely ruin the pace of a scene if the syncing is too forced. 
One of the reviews I've read for Baby Driver states that "Baby Driver is a worse Fast and the Furious." First of all, The Fast and the Furious does not come close to the level of cinematography Baby Driver possesses. The Furious movies all rely on over the top action scenes to compensate for the lack of variety and substance behind their car chases. For example, the most recent Furious movie shows a car escaping from being harpooned by five other cars, then it's back to a normal car chase. The camera angles that the Furious movies use are repetitive and boring due to how basic they are. The level of quality that the Furious series has been cultivating for many years was surpassed the moment Baby Driver hit theaters. 
Baby Driver's cinematography and soundtrack make the movie into an amazing experience that any watcher will be satisfied by going to. The multiple intricacies in the movie's creation really add to the overall quality of the movie, and it makes the average moviegoer really appreciate the amount of work that goes into it. Whether it's a car chase or an on foot chase, Baby Driver makes a masterpiece out of it.

title: Love this! Great fun and great music!
review:
Baby is a young man (Ansel Elgort) who is tantamount to a stunt car driver, though he's not a pro. He works for a criminal (Kevin Spacey) as a wheelman after robberies as a way to pay him back for stealing from him some years earlier. He hides the money he makes in the floorboards of the apartment he shares with his foster father (C.J. Jones), who is deaf and in a wheelchair. The two sign to one another. That's good, because Baby doesn't talk much. He spends all tie listening to music via his earbuds - he has tinnitus from a childhood accident that killed his parents.

Baby meets a waitress, Debora (Lily James) and falls for her - she doesn't know what he does. And the latest robbery involves some violent and very nasty characters (John Bernthal, Jon Hamm, Jamie Foxx, Elza Gonzalez). And that puts Baby, Joseph, and Debora in danger.

Really excellent film with unbelievable car chases. Elgort has great moves as he dances around listening to his tunes. He underplays, but his feelings read in his face. The rest of the acting is excellent; Spacey and his gang are mean as dirt.

Highly recommended.

title: Baby Blasts 2017
review:
Just....so, so, so good. That's all you need to know!

If you love any of these: music, Action, car chases, Edgar Wright films, Atlanta and Lily James, you will adore this film! Having spent a lot of time in Atlanta, this film acts as a love letter to the city. It's incredibly well shot and directed, with so many Easter eggs (including a Pierce Brosnan cameo) It has a very warming story, yet series and dark themes sprinkled all the way through, creating a well balanced, enjoyable action film. It truly is on of the better films I've seen in recent years, if not this decade. Only thing that pulls it down is the 2nd act. Although it's still good, the pace here slows down, yet Baby and Debora's relationship develops rather fast. Apart from this.....it's movie perfection!

title: One of the best movies in some time
review: Great action. Great music. Great cast. Anyone who didn't like this movie was not in the right mindset when they watched it.

title: Baby drives fast
review:
Just got out of the film Baby Driver. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. The film was a nice mix of comedy, white-knuckle thrills, and in your face action. There really wasn't much that I didn't love about this movie.

The way the film was built around the soundtrack was interesting and fun. I would be hard-pressed to name a film that meticulously worked with a soundtrack of the way Baby Driver does. Every song is at the centerpiece of a scene and they almost feel like roles in them self. Of course it helps to be soundtrack is just all around awesome also. Baby driver has a Guardians of the Galaxy level good soundtrack.

The action scenes were all well choreographed and entertaining. The chase scenes were some of the best I've seen in years. It is impossible not to have fun watching Baby drive. The choreography with some of the best I've seen all year.

The plot of the move is simple enough. Boy drives cars fast to help rob banks. Boy meets girl. Boy falls in love with girl. Bad things happen and boy must save girl by driving fast. Simple, sweet, and a lot of fun. Mixed in is a rogues gallery of interesting characters that all have a life of their own.

It also had just the right amount of charm in the plot and characters. Really solid film all around 9 out of 10.

title: An unexpected gem
review:
Baby is a genius behnd the wheel, and finds himself working as a getaway driver for a local crime boss he is indebted to. Orphaned as a child, when his parents died in a car accident which also left him with a severe case of tinnitus, Baby always have a soundtrack to his life. Finally free from his debt, he meets Debora, and dreams of hitting the highways with her. But he is forced to do one last heist for his old boss, and naturally things unravel...

A movie with high speed, both on the roads and in the pace of itself. Quick and elegant with good pieces of car pursuit and action. But it also has another level to it. Baby and Debora, among others, are likeable characters. The humor is good, but above all; the sound and soundtrack is masterfully used. It lines up perfectly with the acting and events in the movie. It kind of becomes a character of it's own, and sound and hearing is a theme throughout the movie. A little more forgotten is the use of colors. There clearly is a thought behind them, as striking colors are often used in the movie. In such, Baby Driver is a treat both visually and audibly. Director Wright and his team have done a really good job here.

An unexpected gem.

title: Future cult classic
review: This movie was a lot of fun. Great action. Just overlook having to watch the pervert Kevin spacey. Of which I think a lot of the reasoning for the bad reviews.

title: Surprise Hit
review: Some of the best car chases seen since Ronin. It was a lot better than expected. Everyone plays their parts well.

title: It was good. Not great, but really good.
review:
Now having watched, not sure quite what all the hype was about. This wasn't a major difference in film making, like say "Pulp Fiction" was. This was more of an evolution of using music as a central plot device.

That said, it was good. Certainly worth watching.

title: Sounds and action that keep your heart racing and your ears singing
review: The visual, musical and all around cinematography make this an instant classic. It will forever be a favorite of mine. The story never stops as the main character grows from something infantile into something unstoppable. The makers of Sean of the dead really kicked it up a notch in every aspect. Do yourself a favor and watch this movie!

title: High Octane Thrills and Unfortunately High Octane Language.
review: Baby Driver Directed by Edgar Wright is a high octane thrill ride that pushes the limits of car chase scenes, splendid editing, fast moving script and PUNCHY music. The standout facet of this movie is the soundtrack that plays like a very long mixtape. The songs are placed accordingly and once again pushes the limits of an action movie,aside from all that there happens to be one quibble that I have...the language, to me language use is obnoxious, disconcerting and is an excuse from writing additional dialog. To me if this had been PG-13, minus some of it's not frequent gore it still would have been a spectacle.

title: Great Movie
review: So the kid at coffee shops picture is before Lillie James give me a break self promoting jerkoff.

title: Favorite movie
review: I have never given a movie a 10/10 because that would mean that the movie is perfect, this movie is not perfect but, it being my favorite movie gets it a ten. My favorite thing about this movie was the way that music was a part of the action. Being a musician, i can appreciate when things that are happining in the movie are in sync with the beat of the song that is playing. There are also lots of great details that you can easily miss that make the movie even better.

title: As good as this kind of movie can be!
review:
This movie is really fun. Everything is on point. The pace is fast and the editing is part of the cast, like with most Edgar Wright movies. It's visually beautiful and the characters have enough interesting quirks to make them unique (even when they are basically archetypes). It's impossible to be bored with this movie.

Having said that, there is romance and is rushed; the crime scenes are a bit undercooked; the plot/story is clichÃ© for the most part.

All these things seemed on purpose to make the movie more fun and fast paced though, so they don't harm the experience, they just don't elevate the film into more than good.

title: Movie 6 Sountrack 10
review:
So I give this movie 7. It started as really good and it was entertaining and longer and longer it took this film i was more and more bored. I mean why you kept it going after that busted robbery scene was just stupid. Pretty much it killed the this movie.

Soundtrack was amazing. One of the best in years. Shame that this movie was not.

title: One of the best movies this year
review: Not many good movies make me cry. Well this ine did. It had some mistakes in it other than that it's very fun and emotional to watch. Excellent

title: Wonderful movie
review: This is one of the best movies that I've ever seen in my life. The music were so amazing. Those music inspired inside me and resounded my heart deeply. The rhythm completely matched the action of actors so that's why it made me get adrenaline and i i got addicted to this movie. You should watch it!!!

title: Wright strikes again
review: A fantastic film that's so bright and lively baby driver is an amazing watch, truly compelling and with a fantastic beat the action seemingly never stops, all of this is bumped by an amazing cast who all knock their performances out of the park and absolutely brilliant movie

title: Boring
review: Really don't understand 90 percent of the movie if you want to waste time in your life watch this movie

title: Now this is a good thriller with good acting
review:
I had a laugh reading how some people wrote stuff as this was advertised as a Cannes winner or something.

It's a thriller with good driving sequences. Sub-genre that has it's rules.

That keeps it way ahead of the usual pack is acting. At least 4 actors created great miniatures that the'll be proud to mention even in 10 years.

This is why I'm so sorry that Lily James allowed herself to be attached to that stain named "Mamma Mia". This is the caliber that she can actually do. Given the good director who knows his light sculpting (watch her face, compare to "Mamma Mia" - huge difference).

Jon Hamm also good, as expected, Ansel Elgort, interesting surprise (for people not in the know it takes a lot of discipline and skill to do that kind of frozen face, but steaming and ready to explode), even Kevin Spacey was good (I don't expect anything from him, ever :-) and Jamie Foxx had his on bats-crazy sub-show (proving that that Oscar wasn't political).

The "problem" this flick has is that it is ensemble piece and they never get Oscars since they can't have distinctive "stars' by definition and Academy keeps stubbornly refusing to add ensemble award.

title: Brilliant
review: I have grown up around race cars and this was just on the edge of your seat stuff! Brilliant actors and actresses! Lily and Ansel are wonderful together, good chemistry and on screen connection. Loved it. One of my favs.

title: great car chase scenes and music
review:
I really enjoyed this movie because of the real (non CGI) car chases and the use of a constant soundtrack. The stars of the film give great performances. The movie even holds up on second viewing.

One of the coolest things I read about the lead actor is that he asked the director if he could have the Subaru WRX from the beginning of the movie. He ended up getting it as a birthday present.

Overall, you feel good when you finish watching this and it doesn't seem that cheesy or far-fetched, which is often the biggest problem with heist movies.

The soundtrack is great with everything from hip-hop to country. And there are quite a few stars if that's what you're into.

Also, the girlfriend character and the diner reminded me of the diner from the original Twin Peaks. Not sure if that was intentional.

title: The most amazing I've ever seen...
review: Amazing. From the start to the end makes you see the story inside you. Amazing...

title: loved the humor in this robbery gone wrong adventure
review:
The best part about this movie was the dark humor and one liners. It just worked. And I loved the character of Baby, it just works you have this quiet guy listening to music and he can do all these cool tricks with a car. Spacy was good as the ringleader in all this. Not only were the car chase scenes excellent, but the on the foot scenes well shot too. Some parts I still don't get. Like why did Baby slam on the gas and run into the back of the truck on the last heist. It's like he wanted to give up but then he ran. And I don't think he should have gone back the waitress while on the run. He knew what would happen. Just look over some of the plot holes.

FINAL VERDICT: Super fun robbery film with some humor. Definitely worth checking out.

title: Good hyperkinetic caper yarn
review: Ansel Elgort is 'Baby", a young, music-obsessed driver in thrall to criminal kingpin 'Doc' (Kevin Spacy) who uses him as a getaway driver for number of increasingly bloody robberies. Baby, who is always plugged into music and records much of what he hears, is viewed with suspicion by the various hard-cases hired by Doc, ultimate leading to a climatic showdown with psychotic 'Buddy' (John Hamm). The film is darkly comic but not a broadly funny as director Edgar Wright's earlier films (i.a. Shaun of the Dead (2004) Hot Fuzz (2007). The driving scenes, which are primarily practical effects (i.e. not CGI) are excellent, the story entertaining (despite being a bit over-the-top and implausible (especially Hamm's seemingly unkillable bad guy)), and the cast and script uniformly good.

title: It is very good, but still flawed
review:
Baby driver

I will say this first, baby driver is very good, but it is flawed. The characters in these movie are not really fleshed out, the back story of baby are shown with flash backs, and the consequences plays a major role in the movie, it is what makes baby special as an character. But the rest of the cast are pretty weak, and I'm not saying that baby's character is great, because it's not, all I'm saying is, everyone is serviceable, it's good enough.

Now I will start talk about the stuff I like and then i will talk about the things I don't like. The movie looks beautiful, it's full of color, the lighting is great, characters have their own color, visually look spectacular. Edgar Wright's other films such as Hot Fuzz and Shaun of the Dead, both amazing films, but the color palette aren't that impressive to me. And you just can't not talk about the music in the movie, the choice of music is absolutely amazing, Edgar wright didn't just throw all these great musics into his movie, every song he picks fits with what is gong on, and it doesn't fee; cheap at all, because he in sinks the action with music. When I rematched the movie, I just can't help to think, how did he do it, every movement is apart of the music. When you pat attention to the sound design, noises on the street, bells ring when you walk in, every thing is apart of the music, as long it is part of baby's character. It is absolutely crazy, it is so creative and impressive, that every time I watch it, it's just jaw dropping. And the car scenes, it is probably the best I've ever seen. It's not like Fast and Furious, people just drive really fast and crash into each other, it looks fancy, every stunt they pull of looks absolutely unreal, it looks like something only happens when kids play around with Hot Wheels cars, it's so cool! When I say the characters are serviceable, I don't mean they are bad acted, I think it is very well acted. I really can't name any character that is bad acted, I think this is the best I have ever seen Jamie Foxx performed, he is a very good villain, he is really threatening.

Now I'm done with the good stuff, now it is time to start with the bad stuff. I really don't like the love story in this movie, I just don't buy it at all. I think all the story that doesn't do anything with the girl is great, but when she is on screen, the story just drops for me. I do understand they fall in love, but it happens so fast, they don't have enough screen time together, every thing just feel so rushed. I can see that they are in love, but I can't understand why would she give up her life for Baby!? It just doesn't make any sense to me. I am not convinced at all on this relation ship, the second she say she will go with baby, I feel like this is full of rubbish. And the last part of the movie, is not good as the rest of the film, the quality dropped a little in my opinion, there are some cheese lines, but I will let it pass.

Everyone can tell that they put in a lot of effort in to the movie, and it definitely paid off, there are certain elements in this movie are just way too good, but this is not a perfect movie, there are flaws, but it is over shadowed by all the good stuff in this movie. I feel like we will never get a film like this, ever, because it is so unique, the action and music combine is so hard to top, that I really don't see people will try to do the same thing. It is good, and I defiantly recommend this movie.

title: Easy to watch
review: I find Baby Driver very easy to watch. It's not a boring movie and Ansel is a great actor but I just couldn't seem to take it very seriously as an action movie. It's entertaining though!

title: Bomblastic Baby!
review: Straight to ma hearts one of altime favourite,From start to end Awsome song mix with super Car chase. To jaw dropping stunts.Includes an awsome back story.With wonderful cast and cars.Accompanied by a love too.... Put your seat belts and Enjoy this awsome ride ! 5/5

title: If the last 40 minutes of the movie could be the whole movie...
review: First off, the last 40 or so minutes of the movie was amazing! Sadly, the beginning was offensive and cringe-worthy. Whether it was calling disable people retards or slow or getting unneeded, ubsceen close ups of one of the main actresses behind, the movie made me feel like there was no need to watch it. At least when I was just about to fall asleep, it got good and was the only reason this movie can get a 5 star for the half job they did.

title: Strangely depressing
review: My brother recommended this film to me a while ago and I finally got around to watching it. At first I thought the whole thing was just going to be 2 hour Subaru WRX commercial but it certainly was not, as the vehicle changes on each op and Baby's skills are exceptional in any 4-wheel vehicle. This is not a happy movie, there is a dark sense of humor and some moments of hope. This is a movie about kid getting in or being put in situations he shouldn't, and having to choose right and wrong for himself and those around him.

title: Its enjoyable because Edgar Wright did it
review:
Another great example by Edgar Wright on how incredible editing and music editing can make an actually pretty straightforward movie interesting.

Perfect song choices, really good sound design as always, not a very unique story which also gets kinda cheesy sometimes and hollywood car-chase sequences we are all far too familiar with.

Its about a driver whose name is "Baby" that drives criminals to safety. Of course things get out of hand.

title: Really really cool! Edgar Wright all the way
review:
I didn't see this film in theatre, and boy I do regret that! Right from the first minute, the film keeps you engrossed. The dialogues are witty. The chase sequences are marvellous. Acting is great. Jamie Foxx totally kills it whenever he's on screen!

The story is pretty simple but it's the way Edgar Wright has directed, makes this film so unique. I really don't understand the negative reviews this film has got by some people. I'd rather watch Baby Driver 3 times in a row than watching some "classic" movie released 40 years before my birth and saying that it's good just because others think so.

Ansel Elgort does a fine job, but I wish they had a better actor than him. The supporting cast is stellar. Spacey does his role perfectly, so do Lilly James and Jon Hamm. But the standout is Jamie Foxx. Delivering dialogues with such humour yet with even more threat, something that he does effortlessly.

Overall, baby driver is an awesome movie with nail biting chases and quick witted dialogue. And yeah, the music is really great, in spite of me not hearing any of the songs used in the movie. See, that's a good film. Not the one where you "don't get it" but convince yourself that you do.

title: I Don't Think Edgar Wright Can Make A Bad Film
review: Sure this film wasn't on the level of the Cornetto trilogy, but it was really my first time seeing an Edgar Wright film starring Hollywood A-Listers. It was a really well done film and feels completely different from what I'm used to seeing, but it works. I may have rated this film lower than his other films, but that doesn't mean I didn't really enjoy this film.

title: Thank You Edgar
review:
Edgar Wright's style has always been right on target. His unique and challenging approach to making films creates gems that are destined to become classics.

I thoroughly enjoyed the characters and the high-speed storyline.

title: Shallow characters, but great music and entertaining action
review: First off, given that the movie is centered around a completely ridiculous premise (that driving really fast is the way to get away with crime), I came in with low expectations, which is good, because you won't find much here in terms of character depth or development. The plot is Hollywood at its "finest" (good guy beats bad guy and gets/saves helpless girl). But the action is very entertaining, the dialog is mildly funny (again, don't over-analyze it (and by "over", I mean "at all")), and the soundtrack is fantastic (thank you Guardians of the Galaxy for inspiring this). So if you're looking for a bit of brainless entertainment, consider Baby Driver.

title: Great action packed wholesome entertainer with a problematic climax
review:
The best thing about 'Baby driver' is that the flow of the plot manages to keep the viewer invested in the main character 'Baby' .
By which I mean that the scenes work out so good that it makes us feel Baby's insecurities and the struggle he has to go through in order to make the decisions he makes.
The action sequences are greatly directed.
There was no moment in the action scenes that felt illogical or unrealistic.
Combined with all of the above assets the film also gets benefited by its talented star cast including Ansel Elgort (The most compassionate character)and Jamie Foxx ( The most unlikable character) with their convincing performances.
The film also would serve strains of dark comedy.
The only negative aspect of the film in my opinion is its problematic climax
Specially with the character arch of Doc (Played by Kevin Spacey) who favours Baby in an unimaginable and ridiculous twist.
Watch this movie for Ansel and for its realistic and excitement boosted action sequences.

title: A wonderful 2 hours of fun, excitement and style
review: OK i can see where those that didn't like this film are coming from but I loved it. Style is key here 100% style from the first frame to the last. Excitement, fun , laughs and a good story. Great cast, well acted and just 2 hours of pure entertainment. Loved it.

title: Using soundtrack while taking an action
review:
Just watched it 7 months ago and it was a very great movie. Ansel's is a great actor and Lily James also a great actor. Wanna know jamie foxx who stared in Django? Jamie foxx played as bats is good, some bad guys are good too.

The music is awesome. action scenes were great and the cinematography is great too. This is the best Edgar Wight film since Hot Fuzz. I haven't seen shaun yet, but the world's end done watching on hbo with malay dub. I hope will be make a sequel.

title: Poetry in motion at breakneck speed
review: This film is brilliant. It's a love story, perfectly choreographed to music. It's just so refreshingly rare nowadays to find films that are heavy on live action sequences while light on CGI: this is one of those films. One of the best films 've seen in years.

title: High speed nostop ride
review: Scene after scene Edgar Wright keeps the films nostop pace going and there is never a dull moment. The witty dialogue and fun action sequences make this one of the most fantastic movies I've seen and I highly recommend it.

title: Baby Driver Wins With Audiences
review:
Baby Driver is a clever, fast-paced, crime/thriller film. It is directed by Edgar Wright, and stars Ansel Elgort, Lily James, and Jamie Foxx. Baby Driver has a perfect mix of everything: action, comedy, a love story, and a bit of a tragedy. 
 The combination of up and coming with established Hollywood stars gives the movie a perfect balance. Baby (Ansel Elgort) and Deborah (Lily James) share an unconventional romance that captivates the audience from the start. 
 Baby Driver has an outstanding soundtrack. Somehow, the mixture of The Beach Boys, Queen, and the Commodores creates a confused, tense mood. The music is often out of sync with the plot line, being more upbeat than the actual mood of the scene. The use of music mesmerizes the audience.

title: Didn't make it all the way through
review:
To be honest, this film lost my interest in the first 10 minutes. I really don't know how these scripts get accepted through all the levels of Hollywood bureaucracy before being made into a movie. Millions of dollars spent on something so dumb and mediocre.

The opening bank heist where he is meant to be some super getaway driver makes absolutely no sense. If he is that good why does he go screeching off backwards, drawing massive attention to himself with no clear plan of escape relying on pure luck to get away (the almost identical red cars on the highway that just sit there while a maniac driver races around them!!) Who would do that? Who would hire him again? Yes, I realise that it is for cinematic effect but it just makes no sense, and I have no time for movies that make no sense.

The good points. The soundtrack is great. The action sequences are well done and very entertaining but this cannot make up for a flawed screenplay.

title: best film since love on a leash.
review:
This film makes my mouth water every time I watch it, I loved kevin space, ansel esgort, lily james. the soundtrack is simply the best (behind love on a leash, I mean I just adore the purposeful silence).

problems.

Jamie foxx was much much much better in ANNIE!!!!!!!!

read the rview named misleading it is so true!!!

title: Love it
review: The ending goes a little out there but otherwise it is an amazing film.

title: Amazing
review: Loved it. Well don humour, exciting chase scenes, you never know what direction the film will take.

title: A Fun Film That Has Unique Cinematography And I liked That But...
review:
My Personal Rating: 7.3/10

Conclusion: Baby Driver is a film that most people will enjoy because of how action packed it is, but not in a dumb way and actually in a way of interesting cinematography, also the protagonist is actually interesting but it had some cheesy and predictable story.. but if you ask me it is still worth a watch especially if you only care about good cinematography, this film has that and i liked it because of that.

Pros:

  • Great Cinematography
  • Great Sound Design
  • Uniquely Made Car Chase Scene


Cons:

  • Story Is Predictable
  • Has Some Cheesy Scenes
  • The Girl Of Baby in My Opinion is Really Unnecessary


Rating On Each Aspect

  • Story: 6/10
  • Cinematography: 8.5/10
  • Atmosphere: 7.5/10
  • Soundtrack: 7.5/10
  • Acting: 7/10
  • Dialogue: 6.5/10

title: Great catchy movie!
review: Realy liked the movie, besides some plot holes/errors, it was really fun to watch. Soundtrack was perfect also, loved the fact that beats were synced to the movements.

title: One of the best movies of 2017
review:
This movie didn't really get a whole lot of hype. I think I remember seeing the trailer maybe once in the movies and I'm a frequent movie goer. Thankfully though, it was a success, financially and critically.

The story is of Baby, an expert car driver, who is paying his debt to a shrewd businessman (Spacey), who overseas a heist operation. Baby doesn't talk much but he carries one helluva stick, his driving skills. The movie is also all about the music. Just about every scene is shot in a sort of music video style, with all the action and movements of the characters going to the beat of the particular song that's playing. Baby was in a car accident as a child and got permanent tinnitus, so he always has music in his ear to drown out the ringing, which is why we as the audience hear a lot of music. The song selections are absolutely perfect and eclectic.

The chase scenes are shot really well and manage to capture the intensity of being in a car that's moving fast, without the use of shaky cam or edits ad nauseam.

The cast of characters is well put together. The lead is relatively unknown but he does a good job nonetheless. Then, you've got Jon Hamm, Jon Bernthal, Jamie Foxx and yes Spacey (yeah, I know it's cool to hate him now but you can't deny his acting chops).

Every time I watch this movie, it gets better. I don't know why there are so many low star reviews. It was a fun, adrenaline filled blast of a ride.

title: "He's a good kid and a devil behind the wheel."
review: With all the hype that attended the original release of this film, I guess I expected something better. The film's not terrible by any means but there's not a whole lot of story to it and the actor portraying Baby Driver (Ansel Elgort) seemed out of his element in the picture. Come to think of it, I'd be rather resentful if people wanted to call me 'Baby' as a nickname, it has a pejorative feel to it as opposed to someone casually saying 'Hey, Baby'. Which is probably why all the thugs hired by Doc (Kevin Spacey) took an immediate dislike to the kid; he looked too young to be the kind of experienced getaway driver that the film called for. But the action driving sequences were well staged, even though there probably should have been more of them given the fast car genre this picture falls into. Also, if I had my way, I wouldn't have led off the picture with the best stunts. There was one maneuver that looked outrageous that I'd find hard trying to describe, but if you've seen the picture you can probably narrow it down. I think I would also have opted for a single, intricately plotted heist at the center of the story, but since it wasn't my call, you have to take what you get.

title: Baby Driver Short Review
review: A very colorful fun and entertaining thrill ride. Edgar Wright manages to direct a well structured and well executed film with memorable scenes and action moments coupled with an amazing soundtrack that sync to the world so good. The plot was good, yes you can predict what's going to happen next but you never know how will happen. Characters are well developed and well performed by the performers while some of them didn't like for the character "Bats" played by Jamie Foxx performance was underwhelming that feels like he is playing a wrong character while Kevin Spacey(sigh) didn't do much but at least he embodies the character and he does look good wearing a suit . Overall the film is masterfully directed with memorable characters and well used soundtrack with a amazing action scenes and beautiful cinematography, you will not be disappointed watching this damn good film.

title: Over the top drama.
review:
Baby Driver starts very well but then nose dives.

The film does have some great acting talents and seems to be a very promising film at start, but as the story progresses (specially the later half) it becomes very clear that the film is going towards a very cliched ending. A very hyped out movie but can be a bit disappointing for audience.

title: B-A-B-Y
review: This movie was very good. I love it. Hüloggggggggggg

title: Captures some Summer Classic Romance, but Weaves off Track it's Real Special Path
review: Even when the movie spins out of whack and becomes a senseless reflection of Terminator II, at the heart of Baby Driver is an incredibly resonating and truly unforgettable romance fantasy and tale between Baby and the Waitress that fumes and tunes into a truly magical note that no other movie this summer was able to capture. (7.6/10)

title: Baby Driver
review:
Stupid name for a heist movie, unless that movie is a kids comedy all about a bloke having to drive babies around during a heist. Or maybe an adult who drives like a baby or some sh*t like that. Why hasn't anyone made a comedy about learner drivers yet? You could call it 'Learner Driver', hey that's not a bad idea (copyrighted).

So this is a heist movie. In this movie a mysterious kingpin (?) called Doc (Kevin Spacey) uses various people to pull off various daring jobs, but he always uses the same driver. This driver is a young man called Baby or Miles (Ansel Elgort). Apparently Doc caught Baby breaking into his car many years prior and was so impressed with his skills that he decided to use him for his heists. Naturally Baby had to comply or face the obvious consequences. Now for a long time every heist has gone well for Doc, but clearly that doesn't last and that's the main crux here.

So straight away there are various questions here. Firstly, who is Doc exactly? What is this guys deal? Where does he come from? How is he so powerful? What does he do? Nothing is explained about this character and its kinda frustrating because he simply doesn't come across like a bad guy (especially with Spacey's performance). The fact he also makes such glaring mistakes with his decisions also raises questions about how he's managed to gain so much power. Doc uses Baby as a getaway driver despite the fact he's literally only a teenager, or at least in his early 20's. Yeah OK Baby is a good driver, but is that still a good decision? To use such a young person as your heist getaway driver?? I can think of many problems that might arise with that.

Doc also claims to never use the same people for each heist, but he does! He also uses Baby for every heist so what is he talking about. Then at one point when the gang suspects Baby of being an informant, and the fact he's being telling his foster father all about their deeds; Doc and co still allow him to carry on being their getaway driver! These are what you call eye rolling movie decisions.

Now lets look at Baby, why is he called Baby? Dunno. This young man has tinnitus from an accident as a child (which killed his parents). Since then he's been raised by a black man who is deaf. Is it me or does that sound both unnecessarily pc and kinda counter productive? Would a deaf (apparently single?) man be the right choice to raise a child with tinnitus? I honesty don't know, it just seems like an odd decision, but hey what do I know. So Baby is a good driver, again we don't know how this is, it just is. He's a good driver don't question it. Baby is also very much into his music, mainly because of the tinnitus. He listens to music virtually all the time and uses it to help him concentrate, even on heist jobs. The weird part is he often records people (without consent) and uses snippets of their speech to make mix tapes. Its a very odd part of his character and really doesn't make any sense, or it didn't to me.

So things all go wrong for Doc when he uses a (quota pleasing) team consisting of a couple of crooks who are in love, Buddy and Darling (Jon Hamm and Eiza González), and the violent Bats (Jamie Foxx). Of course the highly predictable outcomes are all a result of the highly predictable out of control character Bats. Because a trigger-happy, tattooed, ghetto lunatic is what you need in your specialised heist team, what could go wrong? The other two don't really do much other than smooch, although Buddy does stick up for Baby at times leading you to think he's a good guy. All the while Doc is supposed to be intimidating...but really isn't.

What follows is a bog standard turn of events that see the plot holes get bigger and bigger. At one point after discovering one of Baby's mix tapes Bats and Buddy decide to go back to his place to get the rest of his stash, and question his foster father. Bats proceeds to knock Baby out...but how did they then manage to find Baby's place?? When the heist goes wrong and the police react, I don't believe any of the cops actually saw Baby involved in any way. Yet Baby runs off, and continues running even when in the clear, which would obviously cause the police to follow out of suspicion (as they would in reality, if you run you've got something to hide). Baby continues to escape by then carjacking and driving like a lunatic...which again will always make you stick out like a sore thumb. Why do characters in movies never get this?? You wanna blend into a crowd of people or traffic, act or drive normally, don't run or drive like a nut.

Anywho the movie is formulaic right down to the last moment where Buddy keeps popping up despite Baby shooting him point blank (in the shoulder?? How did he f*ck that up??). The only thing that got me was the fact Baby didn't go down in a blaze of glory, or escape fully. But then we get this dreadful soppy ending which is even worse so...I find myself baffled by the reaction to this movie, once again I just don't get it. It didn't offer anything much in terms of originality, except for the main protagonist having hearing issues; and everything action wise was terribly average. I think the thing that disappointed me the most was the trailer giving me the impression that Baby drove a Subaru Impreza for the whole movie, which he didn't.

5/10

title: "Easter Eggs" feast
review:
I usually avoid trailers, spoilers, reviews and any stories about movies I have not seen, and when I finally sit down to watch a movie, I do not know almost anything about them. But there was so much hype about this one that even I, who live under the stone, did not manage to avoid being dragged into it. Whether the movie is overrated or the hype has raised my expectations to an unrealistically high level, I'm not sure, but it didn't leave any particular impression on me. So far I saw "Scott Pilgrim vs. the World" which I liked, but saw it so long ago that I shouldn't rate it from this perspective, and "Shaun of the Dead" whom I gave seven a few days ago. As "Shaun of the Dead" is fresh in my memory, I immediately recognized the same director in "Baby Driver" (until that moment I did not know the director for either of these two films).

Wright is great screenwriter and director, but in "Baby Driver" he really made a step forward. I can't remember when I watched such a masterfully directed action. Gunshots and movements of characters in the film are in line with the rhythm of the music that is heard at the moment. And when you take into account that all the driving in the movie was shot without CGI even ten out of ten is not enough. I am also amazed by Wright's sense for details and quantity of "Easter eggs" hidden in this film. When Baby is flipping through the channels on TV, several lines of dialogue from different movies can be heard. Each one of these lines appears later in the film as a line of dialogue. In the first scene, when Baby goes for a coffee and listens to "Harlem Shuffle", he passes by the graffiti, signs, and posters that show the text of this song. In this scene, you can also see the reflection of Wright in the shop window. It's shot by accident but left in the movie on purpose. It instantly reminded me of Hitchcock. There are several references to "Back to the Future" too. One of the cars in the movie has a license plate that represents the date when Wright's previous film came out. Singer whose song is played during the first robbery plays guard. While listening to "Radar Love" song, Baby drives a car painted in "Radar Purple". There are countless details like these and even if you watch the movie a dozen times you won't even catch a half.

Still, no matter how directing, soundtrack and sense of detail are perfect, in other aspects, this film is nothing special. Acting is good but, in my opinion, wasted on unoriginal characters. The story is mediocre and the atmosphere of the movie didn't move me. It was fun to watch but I forgot most of it very next day. I may watch it again, but only because I'm curious to try and find some more eggs that I missed the first time. Overall impression

7/10

title: Not my kind of movie
review: Where to begin... this movie was, to me, an utter disappointment. I had high hopes at the start - interesting concept, great styling -- kind of music video meets Tarantino-- But as it went on, the movie became completely predictable and honestly, kind of silly. I found it a bit stressful to watch at the beginning and felt more like 'OK, let's just get this over with' at the end.

title: A hot ride indeed, but still not a space rocket
review:
If you're reading this then you have probably read a lot of other reviews by now. So you know the upper sides of this film. It's fast-paced, full of slick dialogues and hot car chases. Acting isn't exactly stellar, so isn't the story, but both are fine just enough to keep you entertained.

What you might not know is that, despite all its glossy charm and a pretty mighty cast (Kevin Spacey might be an a-hole off stage, but a fine actor he remains), this movie is still a rehash of the old "good guy force-tied to a bad company" story. The old-school soundtrack trope, one which worked so well for Guardians of the Galaxy, is effective in this film too, adding to its mojo, but dig one layer deeper - and everything becomes way too black and white and convenient. Ansel Elgort is charming and handsome as ever, and his character is peculiar but nonetheless charismatic. The bandits each have a one track mind they over-exploit in each scene. And even Doc's latest switch of tune - the "I was in love once" one - is as expected as it is cheesy. All rolling to a finale convenient and satisfying.

I liked Baby Driver for being just what it is - an awesome popcorn flick. It's great at that, never pretending to be anything greater. So if you want to watch a movie to have fun, then choosing this one will make you a happy person. But anything outside the entertainment scenario - including the thought-provoking part - is clearly not what Baby Driver can deliver, no matter how fast it rides. So be straight to yourself and expect no Drive from this film - to avoid any possible disillusionment afterwards.

title: Shiny and cool, but kind of obnoxious
review:
After seeing this movie a week ago and talking to friends and family, I began to truly get a sense of how polarizing this movie is. To start though, I want to note what is remarkable about this movie: the soundtrack of Baby Driver is thrilling and executed with special attention timing. The main character, Baby has a special attachment to his ipod - a plot device that turns what would normally be non-diegetic music (not audible to characters) into diegetic music and thus a way for us to hear to everything Baby is hearing.
What this should have provided is a window into the character and a way for us to relate to Baby. However, where this movie falters and what I believe is its critical failure is how unremarkable but still cocky Baby is. We know that we are supposed to care for this guy (evidenced by the contrived heartfelt, yet superficial backstory that the writer threw in), yet I couldn't care about him less.
None of the characters are that interesting and the story completely lacks emotional depth. All this serves to turn what could have been an entertaining, fast-paced heist movie into another shiny, stylish blockbuster that thinks it's hot sh*t. Meanwhile, I was left wishing Baby would get hit by a bus.

title: unnecessarily loud and annoyingly violent
review: Was intrigued by the super high ratings this movie received but I was disappointed. While the soundtrack was impressive and cinematography pretty well done, I found the film unnecessarily loud and annoyingly violent. As always, Kevin Spacey is very good at playing a bad guy and the directing reminded me of Quentin Tarantino. See it if you like but be forewarned...let's just say when we walked out of the theater, I'm glad I wasn't driving...

title: Baby oozes out entertainment
review: The movie Baby Driver is a unique take by Edgar on heist. The Screenplay is fast and engaging and an ensemble cast makes the viewer clinched onto the seat. Something that stands out in the movie is the relationship between Doc and Baby that has subtle layers other than being coerced by doc, Baby too enjoys his role in the team. Deborah's character even though has few scenes has been performed exceptionally well and Kevin Spacey as Doc is once again absolutely brilliant. Overall, Baby Driver is a must watch of 2017 and Ansel should be rewarded for such a beautiful performance yet again!

title: A Yes
review:
Good

A piece of art is either Good or Bad. A Yes, you would recommend it to others or a No, don't waste your time

title: Quite "unoriginal" but well done
review:
Yeah of course the traditional "one last job gone wrong" story is kind of overused but Baby Driver makes you care and is well directed. 
Characters are interesting, for what tey are, music is well paced and chosen, even the simili-twist works.

title: Family fun with a car and a gun
review:
On first viewing I knew I loved this film on a gut level, but on an intellectual level I could not quite figure out why. It took a second viewing to allow some of the elements that had registered sub conciously to register with my slower concious mind. I will not spoil the fun of discovering these "extras" for yourself, suffice to say that when you start looking, and listening, you will be astounded at how much more is going on than at first we realise.

Some critics have actually criticised this as being a bit kitsch, or too cutesy by half, but I say, "go suck a lemon, you miserable gits. Crack a smile and give yer ass some competition." The action is great, the violence is strong, but not gory, the music brilliant and as critical to the plot as any movie I've seen. Then we have the two main characters being really well played by Ansel Elgort and Jon Hamm, delivering far more than the one dimensional fare usually portrayed by protagonists in action films.

So I rate this higher than your average getaway flik, because it delivers so much more than just action, it brings tons of fun. More than once.

title: Reasonably Neat Neat Neat
review:
Baby Driver is a fun film with nothing too offensive, or unfortunately thrilling, to make any real waves. It has a few too many clichés in it to be taken seriously but they don't detract hugely from the viewing experience.

Jamie Foxx is about the best thing, acting and character-wise but that's not saying a whole lot. However, nothing in the cast is so appauling that it spoils the film. Kevin Spacey's character comes close though, as the somewhat nerdy looking but oh so terribly tough gangster that seems to come for free with most movies of this kind nowadays.

It's a good fun popcorn movie without being just a load of typical studio CGI garbage but don't expect a serious thriller. Think Pulp Fiction without the wit or originality.

My review might sound a bit scathing but I did find it to be a good watch, if at times I had to grit my teeth silently.

title: Don't mess with this Baby!
review:
One of the stylish film of the year. There's nothing special about the story, but the way it was made looks intriguing. The individual characters, music, stunts, obviously car chases. Not the best role Ansel Elgort has ever played, but in his short, beginning of the career, it quite possibly defines he's ready for the tough roles. Then the British filmmaker known for some wonderful action-comedies, one more addition to his hit kit.

A youngster who is a getaway car driver for heists, working under a criminal mastermind, is often teamed with a different crew. One of his latest job takes an unexpected twist, leaving his yet to bloom romance with a waitress in peril. His attempt to come out of that, the risk he takes, changes his life forever. The tale ends with an action packed finale.

This is the first Kevin Spacey film I'm seeing after all the allegation against him. I blame everyone equally who had let him do it all these years. But that's nothing to do with this film.
